channel.title: My personal website
channel.description: Recent content in tutorial on My personal website

item.title: Mkdir
item.description:
Go back to your home folder.

user@name:/$ cd ~
user@name:~$

Creating our first directory

Command for making directories is mkdir which has to have a name of folder as parameter for it to create directory on specified path. Note! Look out for capitalized letters, since it is not the same naming directory project or Project. I will demonstrate this bellow

user@name:~$ mkdir Project
user@name:~$ cd Project
# !If we named our folder with capital letter we need to enter a specific name, cd project won't work!
user@name:/Project$ mkdir documentation
user@name:/Project$ mkdir program
user@name:/Project$ ls -l
total 8
drwxrwxr-x 2 user user 4096 Jul 29 14:41 documentation
drwxrwxr-x 2 user user 4096 Jul 29 14:41 program

We can create multiple folders at once

user@name:/Project$ cd program
user@name:/Project/program$ mkdir dir1 dir2 dir3
# we need to space out wanted directories 
user@name:/Project/program$ ls -l
total 12
drwxrwxr-x 2 user user 4096 Jul 29 14:44 dir1
drwxrwxr-x 2 user user 4096 Jul 29 14:44 dir2
drwxrwxr-x 2 user user 4096 Jul 29 14:44 dir3

touch

touch command behaves the same as the mkdir command but instead of making directories it makes files.

user@name:/Project/program$ touch file1 file2 file3
user@name:/Project$ ls -ltotal 12
drwxrwxr-x 2 user user 4096 Jul 29 14:44 dir1
drwxrwxr-x 2 user user 4096 Jul 29 14:44 dir2
drwxrwxr-x 2 user user 4096 Jul 29 14:44 dir3
-rw-rw-r-- 1 user user    0 Jul 29 14:47 file1
-rw-rw-r-- 1 user user    0 Jul 29 14:47 file2
-rw-rw-r-- 1 user user    0 Jul 29 14:47 file3

Editing files.

item.title: Cd
item.description:
For now we will practise our cd command and get some usefull insites.

Make sure that you are in root directory, if not view this.

Next up we will see how to utilize relative and absolut paths. Type:

user@name:~$ cd etc/
user@name:/etc$

This was example of using relative path.

if we try to that again in our /etc/ folder we would be able to do it, because another etc folder does not exit in that direcotory.

user@name:/etc$ pwd
/etc
user@name:/etc$ cd etc/
bash: cd: etc/: No such file or directory

To futher solidify this we will change our directory to /home/user, and try to change our directory to /etc/ using relative path.

user@name:/etc$ cd /home/user/ # this is absolute path
# Or another very usefull way to change to our home directory is by running 
user@name:~$ cd ~
# From here we will try yo run 
user@name:~$ cd etc/
bash: cd: etc/: No such file or directory
# As we can see, we couldn't change our directory to the etc because the etc folder does not exist in /home/user
# Changing it back to /etc/
user@name:~$ cd /etc/
# This will work because there is a /etc/ folder inside / (root) directory.

Now we will run once again ls -l command to see content of the current directory.

user@name:/etc$ ls -l
total 1392
drwxr-xr-x  3 root root    4096 Jan  4  2022 acpi
-rw-r--r--  1 root root    3028 Jan  4  2022 adduser.conf
-rw-r--r--  1 root root      10 Jul 20 17:31 adjtime
drwxr-xr-x  3 root root    4096 Jan  4  2022 alsa
drwxr-xr-x  2 root root   12288 Jul 27 12:52 alternatives
-rw-r--r--  1 root root     401 Jul 16  2019 anacrontab
drwxr-xr-x  3 root root    4096 Jul 20 18:17 apache2
-rw-r--r--  1 root root     433 Oct  2  2017 apg.conf
... and other thousant files will be listed, yours might be more or less files listed

This will give you a enorumous list of files that you won’t be able to see on your screen. If you want to navigate up and down to see all printed stuff you can use Shift + PageUp/PageDown to scroll the screen.

Take a look of this:

lrwxrwxrwx  1 root root      19 Jul 20 17:35 mtab -> ../proc/self/mounts

Its a linked file that points to the relative path of ../proc/self/mounts. This ../ is saying to go back one directory up, ../../ would mean go two directoires up, ../../../ three, etc. Ex.

user@name:/etc$ cd /usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe/
user@name:/usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe/$ pwd
/usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe
# Now run cd ../ and print directory
user@name:/usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe/$ cd ../
user@name:/usr/share/zoneinfo/$ pwd
/usr/share/zoneinfo
# We can see that we have gone up one directory
user@name:/usr/share/zoneinfo/$ cd ../../../
user@name:/$ pwd
/
# now we are in root folder

clear

clear is the command that clears our terminal. Optionaly you can use Ctrl + l to perform quick clear of the terminal, but it behaves little differently than command clear depending on terminal emulators.

Next: making our first directory!

item.title: Ls
item.description:
This command is used for listing directory contents. If we run it we should get this result:

user@name:/$ ls
bin    dev   lib    libx32      mnt   root  srv  usr
boot   etc   lib32  lost+found  opt   run   sys  var
cdrom  home  lib64  media       proc  sbin  tmp

Additionally we can use different parameters that we can give it to the command, such as ls -l. If we man this command, -l parameter used for long listing format. Meaning it gives us more information about the content of the directory. If we run it in our root folder the following shall be listed:

user@name:/$ ls -l
total 72
lrwxrwxrwx   1 root root     7 Jul 20 17:27 bin -> usr/bin
drwxr-xr-x   4 root root  4096 Jul 27 12:53 boot
drwxr-xr-x   2 root root  4096 Jul 20 17:30 cdrom
drwxr-xr-x  20 root root  4620 Jul 29 11:31 dev
drwxr-xr-x 168 root root 12288 Jul 27 13:10 etc
drwxr-xr-x   4 root root  4096 Jul 20 17:31 home
lrwxrwxrwx   1 root root     7 Jul 20 17:27 lib -> usr/lib
...etc

Explaining the printed collumns

First column

Tells us the priveleges and file types of the content.

Ex. drwxr-xr-x first character of this sequence tells us that if the item is directory, file or link (d - directory, - - file, l - link). Other chartachter will be explained here.

Second column

Idicates how many memory locations/blocks directory/file has.

Third column

Tell us which name of the given file is owner of that file.

Fourth column

Tells us the group owner of the file.

In GNU/Linux systems besides the name of the users there are name of the groups which certain user can belong to. One user can be part of the one or more groups. Ex. if our user belongs to the root group, it could access the root files.

Fifth column

Tells us how much space in bytes given file types contain. Note! 4096 donen’t mean that the given directory with all its content contain 4 Kilobytes, just the given directory without its content contains contain 4K, but the content inside of it are independent files and directories that could contain other files and directories

Sixth column

Tells us the date of last change that has occured .

Seventh column

Tells us the name of the given file/directory.

Back to the cd command.

item.title: Intro
item.description:
Terminal

Terminal is %%TODO!!!!!!%%

In most GNU/Linux distributions common [shell] (TODO) is [bash])(TODO).

In our default shell we can see the user folowed by name of the computer has something intresting following it.

user@name:~$ _
# ~ sign in the shell prompt tells us that we are currently in the users home directory.
  • Note! some default shells might be modified and some users cannot see this printed out in their terminal

ALWASYS USE TAB for completrion

First command

Now we will run our first command. simply enter pwd in our command line and hit enter.

user@name:~$ pwd
/home/user

As we can see, pwd prints out the name of working directory hence the name pwd (Print Working Directory).

NOTE!

All commands in GNU/Linux are case sensitive so we need to keep an eye on what and how we are typing something. Ex. pwd and PWD are not the same, pwd command will print the name of the current/working directory, while PWD won’t execute because that command does not exist.

Must know commands

man

This program is maybe the most usefull program that exists on GNU/Linux systems. On some distributions this program does not come bundled with OS, but on most just work distros it is installed by default. You can check if its installed on your system by running man –version, if it’s not installed i suggest to you that you install it by using package manager (more on that later).What is does it gives a manual for commands that we are not sure how to use it. Example of it:

user@name:~$ man pwd

PWD(1)                  User Commands                 PWD(1)

NAME
       pwd - print name of current/working directory

SYNOPSIS
       pwd [OPTION]...

DESCRIPTION
       Print the full filename of the current working direc‚Äê
       tory.

       -L, --logical
              use PWD from environment, even if it  contains
              symlinks
.
.
.
etc...

–help

Alternatevely to man we can use –help command. It behaves simerarly to the man command but it gives us much shorter answer for using certain command.

cd

Next very important command is that for navigating our file system. That command is cd which stands for change directory. It takes an argument as the path that we want to change directory to. Paths can be absolute or relative.

Now we will change our working directory from /home/user/ directory to / ( also known as root directory ). Simply type:

user@name:~$ cd / # Hit Enter/Return button
user@name:/$      # As wee can see our "~" symbol became "/"
user@name:/$ pwd  # Just to make sure that we are in our root directory
/                 # Returned path

For now i will breake up commands into different pages, so this one doesn’t get too big and confusing. Next up ls command!

item.title: Generating and adding SSH to GitHub
item.description:
Creating ssh key

The first order of business should be that we create SSH key, assuming that we have installed and configured SSH on our system.

Running this command will create our desired key:

ssh-keygen -t ed255519 -C example@githubemail.com

#ssh-keygen <-- how we are going to generate a key
#-t ed25519 <-- is type of encryption
#-C <-- here is the email asociated with that key

Once a command is called the following will be printed on our terminal:

Generating public/private ed25519 key pair.

# It will ask you where do you want to save the file
Enter file in which to save the key (/home/user/.ssh/id_ed25519): 


# This is optional. If you want a more secure connection use a passphrase, otherwise leave it blank
Enter passphrase (empty for no passphrase):
Enter same passphrase again: 

# The rest will be printed automaticaly 
Your identification has been saved in /home/user/.ssh/id_ed25519
Your public key has been saved in /home/user/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
The key fingerprint is:
SHA256:bGDfSMIq2TjS/C7b/ASdxd0JHfasdSxYfjKYJjfwWBdKT0Cs example@githubemail.com
The key's randomart image is:
# image will be shown

Now that we have a key generated, we need to make sure that our SSH agent knows about it.

Starting our ssh agent

eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"

Editing config file inside of .shh

Makeing sure that we don’t or do have config file.

ls ~/.ssh/

If there isn’t, we will crate the config file inside of the .ssh directory.

touch ~/.ssh/config

Now we need to edit that file by entering this:

We have everything created and configured, the only two things left to do is to run this command and add the key to GitHub.

ssh-add ~/.ssh/new_created_key

Adding our ssh key to the GitHub

What we do is put the content of the generated key into GitHub.

cat ~/.ssh/nameOfKey.pub

Trying to access gtihub.com via ssh

ssh -T git@github.com
